bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 16, 1946

div1.p: Hench plans to give Kean a questionnaire regarding his yellow fever experience. Hench also talks about how he came across the original contract between Reed and Fernandez.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 16, 1946
div1.p:
I wrote the enclosed letter some time ago but have held it as I thought
you were not then in the mood to hear of Mrs. Lazear's death. In the meantime
I have your fine note of April 8.

I had intended to be in Washington sooner but so many delays have occurred
that I will not be able to get there until about six weeks from now. I will be
there the first week in June. I have been asked to speak before a group there
and will be having to spend some time in the Surgeon General's Office in behalf
of my chapter for the Surgeon General.

You may wish that you hadn't contacted me so soon because when I get fed
up with my patients and Surgeon General's chapter, I take a few hours off for
my yellow fever hobby. I spent one whole weekend about four weeks ago going over
every letter you and I had ever written each other, checking this and that, and
as a result have written out a questionnaire of about seventy-five questions.
This sounds like a difficult job, but I don't really believe it will be too diffi-
cult. I hope to have it written up in the next week or ten days and send it to
you just for you to look over and mull over. If you wish to postpone the whole
matter until my arrival, we can then have Mrs. Franck in for a session, or should
you prefer, you might want to have her in several times, just for a short time,
and dictate to her whatever you wish. Regardless of the expense, it will be of
tremendous value to me and I am delighted to have you make whatever arrangements
with Mrs. Franck as are necessary, and I insist that she come to your home by
taxi and put that on my bill.

Some of the questions you may think you have answered before. To a cer-
tain extent that is true, but because of slight uncertainties, I have rephrased
some of them. Many of them may not be entirely clear until you and I can talk
over them. I know that in helping me do this, you and Mrs. Kean will be most
careful that you are not tired and that you can do as much or as little of it
as you want from day to day or wait until I come. Now, I am sure Mrs. Kean, if
not you also, will be sorry that you wrote, when you see what your nice letter
has gotten you into!

I have just received such a fine autographed photograph from General
Reed. I am delighted indeed to have it. I heard by an indirect way that Dr.
Foster Kennedy, a noted New York physician, had recently come into possession
of “an important yellow fever item.” I wrote him and what do you think it is--
General Jefferson Kean - 2 - April 16, 1946
none other than the original contract between Reed and Nicanor Fernandez:
He has written me about it and I expect to see him in New York. How do you
suppose he got that? My recollection was that it was in the Surgeon General's
Office. Maybe the man who tried to steal yours was more successful regarding
this one.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
